The President decided to announce that he was firing the ICIG late last night. Instead of leading our nation through a pandemic, he is using the pandemic for cover to again punish a public servant who faithfully carried out his duties.

President Trump fired Col. Vindman and his brother. He fired Gordon Sondland. He fired DNI Maguire. He punishes those who have the courage to stand up to him. And now he is firing ICIG Atkinson, who dutifully worked to uphold the rule of law. https://t.co/wgHrNrmjVF

Throughout our nation's history, ordinary Americans have risen to meet extraordinary challenges. On National Medal of Honor Day, we pay homage to the bravest heroes, who risked -- and in many cases gave -- their lives for their fellow soldiers.

I led a letter today with @RepJayapal and other members of the WA delegation urging @fema and @HHSGov to allow #COVID19 test specimens in WA to be sent to our public health labs that have capacity. This would cut the wait time for results from up to 8 days to only 24-48 hours. https://t.co/PdREZBCrgN

As we all adapt to changes in our daily lives, please continue to let me know how I can be helpful. We‚Äôre in it together ‚Äì so let‚Äôs all keep looking out for each other.

Finally, @RepAdamSmith, @cathymcmorris, and I have reached out to the @DeptVetAffairs to find out what needs to be done to assist the VA hospitals in our districts with continuing to care for veterans while building capacity to help weather the pandemic. https://t.co/q1JIR6KC7Q

As civilian medical facilities around the South Sound have become strained with the #COVID19 crisis, I am in contact with Madigan Army Medical Center to find out what they need to keep caring for patients and prepare to assist with capacity for the region as the virus spreads.

I‚Äôve already been in regular communication with JBLM leadership on several issues that have been raised to my office, and I‚Äôm going to continue working together with the base to get questions answered and issues resolved. https://t.co/jXd5QOKy77

But often the most valuable feedback I get comes from constituents ‚Äì military or civilian, on base or off. I want to hear from you about what‚Äôs working and what‚Äôs not. And as we identify issues, we‚Äôll work to make things right.

As grocery stores remain open and face new challenges, so will commissaries on U.S. military installations. I‚Äôve reached out to the Defense Commissary Agency to ask about their readiness and what they need as they adapt to new realities. https://t.co/soIPZltMf4

As the #COVID19 pandemic continues, we‚Äôre changing our way of life to slow the spread of the virus, at least for the near future. We‚Äôre all going to need to adapt, and that can be challenging. Servicemembers and their families can be particularly affected.

Thank you to @Up4Growth for endorsing the Emergency Rental Assistance Act of 2020. As you point out, our national housing shortage was already straining American families, and we need to be innovative and efficient in getting them relief during the #COVID19 crisis. https://t.co/Qc5K9Ajii6

RT @WADeptHealth: Our new #COVID19 dashboard lets you track case numbers statewide, county by county. Numbers are updated daily. https://t.‚Ä¶
As I've said before, the decisions @GovInslee is making are not easy, but they will save lives. https://t.co/5XyH3SLiJv

‚úÖ I urged @SpeakerPelosi and @RepRichardNeal to reinvest in our nation‚Äôs unemployment benefits to help get Americans through the crisis and back on their feet. We will only keep our economy afloat if we keep workers and families afloat. https://t.co/xfnIi1ZWrD

We need to get cash in the hands of displaced workers quickly and directly. Short of keeping millions of workers on payrolls, unemployment insurance is the best way to provide this economic security ‚Äì and the House proposal significantly expands this benefit by $600/wk

Thank you @SpeakerPelosi and @RepMaxineWaters for putting #FamiliesFirst w/ $100bn in emergency rental assistance in the House stimulus bill, a provision I introduced earlier today. American families need robust housing assistance ASAP and rent is due on April 1st. https://t.co/UzKwPTi8eh

Due to the #COVID19 crisis, many American families won't be able to afford April rent next week. Today I introduced emergency legislation to put $100 billion into rental assistance and expand the number of people who will get help. https://t.co/9IonOWYXOu

Congress must also be bold and even more focused on the needs of working Americans, who face unprecedented economic disruption. The federal government can and must step in to offset the precipitous decline in economic output and maintain aid until families are back on their feet.

The Fed clearly understands the magnitude of the crisis, and I applaud them taking bold action today. These efforts represent a clear attempt to better support regular Americans than in 2008. https://t.co/i7uwtApLie

I‚Äôm speaking with FEMA tomorrow to urge them to use WA‚Äôs Major Disaster Declaration to allow ALL affected Americans to access unemployment benefits‚Äîincluding self-employed or contractors or those who see their hours cut. 

We can‚Äôt leave anyone behind in our economic response.

I stand ready to work with @GovInslee to ensure that Washington families can access cash through unemployment insurance. We must expand unemployment benefits and ensure all displaced workers access the aid they need as quickly as possible. https://t.co/qa4R8lVGgX

#COVID19 doesn't recognize race, ethnicity, or nationality.

We will only keep our community healthy if we all choose to take preventative steps to stop the spread of the virus and recognize that we are all in this shared fight together. https://t.co/x0uaDinOFk

Social distancing is necessary to slow the spread of COVID-19 and protect our families and neighbors. But there are challenges that come with it. @WADeptHealth is sharing some ways to cope with the stress. We're all in this together, even when it feels like we're alone. https://t.co/23Qydb7Inr
I‚Äôm keeping Mark, his family, and his staff in my thoughts tonight. Mark is not just ‚Äúone of the good ones;‚Äù he‚Äôs at the top of that class. https://t.co/CzzOiKvg1G

Now is the time to bolster our social safety net infrastructure and mobilize it to get help to families across the country as quickly as we can. The challenge we face is daunting, and Americans can‚Äôt afford to wait.

Congress should take the next step of ensuring that any individual who has a federal student loan and loses their job should be able to suspend their payments through 6 months beyond the end of the public health emergency and we know the economy has recovered.

4‚É£ Student loan assistance

‚úÖThe President has announced that federal student loan borrowers can suspend payments for 60 days ‚Äì this is an excellent first step. But many Americans may not have fully recovered from the economic fallout within that timeframe.
Now, Congress must step up and ensure that renters receive increased and immediate assistance. We can start by expanding housing voucher eligibility and benefits.

‚úÖPleased that FHFA and the administration have adopted a federal mortgage forbearance program. Families are experiencing tremendous economic disruption‚Äîthis is an excellent first step towards offering certainty and stability to homeowners‚Äô pocketbooks. https://t.co/JMR1jzIA4Y

3‚É£ Pillow, blanket and roof

Housing is the largest monthly expense for American families, exceeding healthcare, food, transportation and education combined. To ensure families can emerge from this crisis, we must provide relief from housing costs.

2‚É£ Keep American families healthy

We must expand benefits for programs like Medicaid and food stamps, and help as many people access them as possible by suspending time limits for eligibility and providing incentives to states to sign up larger %s of their eligible population.

Congress must also ensure that all economically distressed Americans can access aid, particularly contractors and the self-employed. We can do this through Disaster Unemployment Assistance by invoking a Major Disaster Declaration. https://t.co/hBtnWTIiwi

1‚É£ Unemployment insurance.

We're already too late to keep millions on payrolls, but unemployment assistance is the next best way to provide cash directly. We must expand the minimum payment, extend it to 6 months past the end of the crisis, when the economy is back on its feet.

We don‚Äôt have months‚Äîor even weeks‚Äîto get help to those who need it. There are millions of Americans who need assistance NOW.

We don‚Äôt need to reinvent the wheel. The quickest way to we can help is to reinvest in our wide-reaching, but neglected, social safety net. Here‚Äôs how:

Our economic response to #COVID19 must match the speed and size of the crisis. This week, I wrote to Speaker Pelosi outlining policies that can serve as the basis for an effective stimulus package that provides immediate relief to American families. https://t.co/2b5WskGTVX

RT @GovInslee: Now more than ever, we need to look out for one another. 

If you are looking for a way to help protect your community, givi‚Ä¶

As @Chris_ArnoldNPR writes, we can‚Äôt leave renters out of the equation. In addition to mortgage forbearance, I called on Speaker Pelosi and the House to include immediate and increased rental assistance in the next #COVID19 stimulus package. https://t.co/D1n0ztgyxU

I‚Äôm pleased FHFA and the Administration are adopting a federal mortgage forbearance program. Families are experiencing tremendous economic disruption, and this is an excellent first step towards offering certainty and stability to homeowners‚Äô pocketbooks. https://t.co/JMR1jzIA4Y

NMHC Chair David Schwartz on the #YIMBY Act: ‚ÄúThere is no silver bullet to the housing affordability crisis, but prudent and practical bills like this, when used to complement more localized efforts, can have a significant and positive impact.‚Äù https://t.co/edUnVNMPAr

Billy taught us when to listen and when to stand firm. He displayed moral courage in the face of unfairness and brought people of different cultures together around the importance of sustaining the natural world around us. Happy Birthday, Billy. https://t.co/3N3VVtKtRw

After the derailment of Cascades 501 in DuPont, first responders ran towards the wreckage to pull out survivors.

Amtrak should be running toward its responsibility to ensure safe rail travel, instead of hiding behind an arbitration clause. https://t.co/MWgJTwMK0t

The health and safety of your family is my top priority. My latest newsletter has resources to answer questions you may have about COVID-19, the respiratory disease caused by a new strain of coronavirus. https://t.co/oGPA2iTNao

After the tragic Amtrak derailment in DuPont, NTSB investigators told us what we need to do to enhance rail passenger safety. Today we‚Äôre doing it. Thanks to @RepDerekKilmer, @RepRickLarsen, and @MarkAmodeiNV2 for joining me in introducing the Passenger Train Safety Act today. https://t.co/qaYTB2VTa0

Great to chat with Mark Zandi and @EconJared at the @NewDemCoalition lunch today (hosted by my friend and New Dem Chair @RepDerekKilmer!) to discuss our nationwide housing crisis and the ways we can solve it. #MissingMillionsofHomes
https://t.co/TDOZhvXJ1q https://t.co/nFz9IlH3L8

I'm closely monitoring the spread of COVID-19 in King and Snohomish counties. Please visit the Washington State Department of Health (@WADeptHealth) website for the latest developments: https://t.co/va3kXjZrWJ

We are missing millions of homes, and solving our housing crisis will require federal, state and local governments working together towards this shared goal.

Congress is taking a critical first step towards bringing relief to cost-burdened renters and homeowners across America. https://t.co/64swEu9e4I

The House just passed my bipartisan YIMBY Act by voice vote, which will help identify and reduce barriers to housing construction at the local level. Grateful to be joined in this effort with @reptrey @repstevestivers @repannwagner, Rep. Lacy Clay and Chair @repmaxinewaters. https://t.co/MhkANdN2rG
RT @mattyglesias: This is a small reform but worthy one ‚Äî> https://t.co/vtTiJzJpCQ

@mattyglesias At a time when people are actively working to make it even harder to build housing, even a small step in the right direction sends a powerful message.

Keep up your advocacy. It's making a difference.
What a lovely tribute to a great public servant https://t.co/ADxuqj3JYX

@RepTrey @RepSteveStivers @RepAnnWagner @RepMaxineWaters At the federal level, we have assembled a broad coalition committed to ending our housing shortage.

The YIMBY Act is a critical first step towards this shared goal, and I am grateful to my @FSCDems @FinancialCmte colleagues for passing this bill out of committee unopposed.

Thank you @reptrey @repstevestivers @repannwagner, Rep. Lacy Clay and Chairwoman @repmaxinewaters for your leadership on the YIMBY Act. 

Our nation is in the midst of a housing crisis that is driving costs up and stretching families' budgets to the breaking point. https://t.co/G7PA2H2Xe5

The #YIMBY Act just passed the House Financial Services Committee unopposed. This bipartisan bill will help shine light on local housing laws and encourage pro-affordability policies. Thanks to @RepTrey for his partnership on this important housing legislation. https://t.co/RugvpUpTLX

One year ago today, the House passed H.R. 8, the Bipartisan Background Checks Act, which improves background checks to enhance gun safety. It sits on Sen. McConnell‚Äôs desk, along with hundreds of other bipartisan bills the House has passed this Congress. https://t.co/sMFh99YD3j https://t.co/x2wjBMhJyN

Initially, Crandall received the Distinguished Service Cross for his heroism. But on this day in 2007, he was awarded the Medal of Honor, our nation‚Äôs highest award for valor. And today, 13 years later, we honor this local hero‚Äôs service and bravery. https://t.co/2HmPg3ZBkQ

That day, Major Crandall flew 14 flights into heavy fire, switching out helicopters twice when his current aircraft became so damaged that it couldn‚Äôt keep flying. In all, the helicopters under Crandall‚Äôs command evacuated 75 wounded soldiers.

He and his wingman Captain Ed Freeman brought supplies to the front line and evacuated injured troops. When other medevac helicopters refused to land because of heavy enemy fire, Crandall and Freeman returned to evacuate more injured soldiers. https://t.co/iI7tuORSji

On November 14, 1965, Major Bruce Crandall flew an unarmed UH-1 ‚ÄúHuey‚Äù helicopter on missions in the Ia Drang Valley, during the first major conflict between American forces and the People‚Äôs Army of Vietnam.

Bruce Crandall was born and raised in Olympia, Washington. He was a baseball star at Olympia High School, batting a .600 average. When he joined the army, he went through basic training at Fort Lewis. https://t.co/EBsZ1upCjv

It was my honor to join @GovInslee, @BruceDammeier and @edbTacomaPierce to celebrate @James_Hardie‚Äôs investment and expansion of operations in Pierce County. This includes 240 new, good paying jobs in our community. Thanks for having me! https://t.co/9athl25wtq

The legitimacy of our democracy is at stake.

Every day that the President does not act against foreign interference in our elections, he undermines the integrity of those elections‚Äîand the people's faith in our government. https://t.co/opzWi0hBa9

Four years ago today, the bipartisan Indian Trust Asset Reform Act passed the U.S. House. I‚Äôm proud to have been the lead Democratic sponsor on a bill that made it easier for tribes to make their own decisions about how to use their historic lands. https://t.co/5iEGB4pc8f
Today, we remember this shameful chapter in our history and resolve never to let it happen again.
In 1978, the former Puyallup Assembly Center, located on the Washington state fairgrounds, was the site of the nation‚Äôs first Day of Remembrance ceremony.

In the South Sound, the Puyallup Assembly Center (or ‚ÄúCamp Harmony,‚Äù as it was euphemistically called) served as a temporary holding facility for Japanese Americans before they were relocated to prison camps. https://t.co/q5wngnNUqF
On this day in 1942, President Roosevelt signed Executive Order 9066, which called for Americans of Japanese ancestry to be interned.

I‚Äôm proud to represent a community that bands together to thank those who have sacrificed for us. Since 2013, we've collected and delivered over 50,000 valentines to veterans and first responders. Thank you to all of you for making it happen. https://t.co/bMGs23NxHY

Thank you to Senators Sam Hunt and Hans Zeiger (and the whole Washington State Senate) for this honor. I was glad to join you yesterday in Olympia, and I was humbled and moved by your graciousness. https://t.co/ktOYX7mudO

This year #WA10 students made 11,000 valentines for veterans and first responders. That brings our 8-year total to more than 50,000 valentines that we‚Äôve delivered to veterans and first responders in our area. Thank you to everyone who has participated! #ValentinesForVets https://t.co/G0mSHGTJZD

Today we sent President Trump a letter, urging him to take corrective action now. We owe our veterans more than we can ever repay. To make them wait even longer while they suffer from an affliction they acquired in service to our country is unconscionable. https://t.co/WwoaIkqaqh

Over 190,000 sick and dying veterans have waited 50 years to see their conditions added to the list of diseases associated with Agent Orange. That was on track to happen until the administration changed the rules, keeping them from accessing VA disability or health care benefits.

What better way to commemorate 100 years of women‚Äôs participation at the ballot box than to affirm the bedrock principles of our Constitution: that all men and women are equal, and deserve equal protection under the law? https://t.co/nZFAtMesG1
I'm proud that the House voted today to rescind the ratification deadline of the ERA.

Now, we have an opportunity to finally enshrine gender equality in our Constitution--where it belongs. The Equal Rights Amendment passed both chambers of Congress in the 1970s, and ratifying it would be the culmination of more than a century of activism towards gender equality.
Washington was the fifth state in the union to enact women's suffrage in 1910. Early states like Washington helped inspire change on a national level, leading to the adoption of the 19th Amendment.

This year marks the 100th anniversary of the 19th Amendment's ratification, granting women the right to vote. Many of the trailblazers who championed women's suffrage called the Pacific Northwest home, like Emma Smith DeVoe of Tacoma and Mary Arkwright Hutton of Spokane. https://t.co/917yYFehSH

Puget Sound is in trouble. I‚Äôm glad the PUGET SOS Act passed the House last week, but we have a lot more to do in order to #SaveOurSound. We‚Äôre also working on a bipartisan bill to help researchers find new ways to redirect and filter stormwater runoff. https://t.co/WoQCRKja8a

I'm glad to join the @HispanicCaucus in calling for an end to the administration's 'Remain in Mexico' policy. Last year I visited facilities on both sides of the border, and I saw firsthand how this policy undermines our legal asylum system and places families in physical danger. https://t.co/PbeWMa1qRo

Last month I introduced H.R. 5599, the Fulfilling the Promise of the Housing Trust Fund Act, to boost the funding of affordable housing projects at no new cost to taxpayers. We can start to meaningfully move the needle with the resources we already have. https://t.co/TDOZhvXJ1q
